text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with chicken cordon bleu which
that's right we've taken an extremely
delicious yet time-consuming classic and
turned it into a tasty easy to make
open-faced sandwich and why because I'm
an American and that's what we do so
check it out so step one in a saucepan
over medium heat we're going to melt a
couple tablespoons of butter and we're
going to saute some diced up smoked ham
and some diced onion and it's been my
experience over the years the recipes
that say to start by sauteing ham and
onions and butter generally are pretty
tasty recipes so you're going to cook
that ham and onion in the butter for
about five minutes just until the onions
start to turn translucent at that point
I'm going to add a nice pinch of dry
thyme I was going to use fresh but it
was like totally pouring outside and I
didn't feel like going out to the garden
so dry is going to work just fine in
this so I'm going to throw the time in
I'm going to saute that for another
minute I'm going to look something like
that
I'm going to dump in a couple
tablespoons of flour and after we make a
roux we're going to make a very very
very thick bechamel which is going to
hold this whole thing together and we're
going to cook the flour in that butter
for about three minutes at that point I
want you to turn off the heat and dump
in a half a cup of cold milk and the
reason we're turning off the heat is
because this is such a small amount of
liquid and this is going to get really
thick really fast I want you to pour the
milk in and then turn the heat on okay
I'm gonna recommend you switch to a
whisk give the milk a stir turn your
heat back on to medium and we're just
going to cook this for like one minute
and you're going to see as soon as it
comes up to temperature it's going to
get really super thick and I'm actually
going to switch back to the spatula here
as soon as I get the ham unstuck out of

because it's so thick it's not really
going to boil in fact let me stop
stirring here so you can see it it's
just going to kind of bubble up from the

minutes kind of misleading you're
basically just going to cook it for a
minute until it sort of looks like that
so that looks good we're going to turn
off the heat very critical here turn off
the heat once it looks like that and add
in your grated cheese and because we're
doing a take on chicken cordon bleu
we're going to use Greer cheese so we're
going to stir in that cheese there's
going to be plenty enough heat in that
bechamel to melt it so stir that around
till the cheese melts and then we're
a season that with some freshly ground
black pepper some Cayenne a little bit
of salt but be careful depending on how
salty your ham is and a spoon of Dijon
mustard very critical don't leave that
out and then I'm going to give it a
little shot of freshly ground nutmeg
there's something about a white sauce
that has Swiss cheese in it that really
benefits from a little pinch of nutmeg
at that point I decided to throw in the
last two ingredients which are diced
chicken and some diced up dill pickles
not too much but that really is a secret
ingredient in this it really balances
all those other rich ingredients and as
far as the chicken goes i poach the
chicken breasts to use in this but in
the original screenplay this was done
with leftover chicken so the next time
you have some leftover chicken you're
trying to think of ways to get rid of
consider this so once that's stirred in
we're done you can just set that aside
until your bread is prepped so I have
four thick slices of French bread those
are about an inch thick you don't want
to go any thinner than that I'm going to
place those on a sheet pan lined with
foil
I prefer foil to a silicone mat by the
way you're going to get a crispier
bottom and then you're going to
generously butter one side all right and
I mean generously make sure it's
completely coated and once that bread is
coated with melted butter on one side
you're going to flip it over so the
butter side is down and begin topping
with the mixture so you're going to
scoop that on top of the bread you're
going to press it down you're going to
make sure you spread it all the way to
the edges really one of the only ways
you can screw this up is to have your
bread exposed because that could burn in
the hot oven and by putting the mixture
all the way to the edge you're not gonna
have to worry about that alright so once
our mixture is divided between the four
pieces of bread and spread evenly we're
going to finish these by topping with a
little bit of bread crumb I just took a
little bit of plain bread crumb and
mixed it with a few drops of melted

little bit it's gonna give that top a
little extra crunch and then just a
little bit more grated Gruyere cheese
and finally a little dusting of cayenne
so they know it's one of ours and that
is ready for a hot oven so we're going
to place that in a preheated 425 degree
oven for between 15 and 20 minutes or
until it looks this awesome I'm sorry if
this sounds immodest but that totally

you want four degree burns I didn't
